title: How to Grow Heirloom Tomatoes

steps.headline: Buy your seeds from a reputable source.
steps.description: There are several online sources for heirloom seeds.

steps.headline: It's important to start germination early.
steps.description: For most temperate zones, you'll want to start around March.

steps.headline: Plant the seeds indoors in small pots about 6 to 8 weeks before moving them to the garden.
steps.description: Some gardeners use foam cups to plant the seeds indoors.

steps.headline: Plant the seeds in sterile soil about 1/8-inch deep in the small pots.
Keep the soil moist until the seedlings emerge.
Make sure the seedlings get plenty of light.
steps.description: Use natural sunlight or fluorescent lights.

steps.headline: Move the plants to larger pots once leaves appear.
Harden off the seedlings by gradually placing them in a cold environment.
steps.description: Be sure the temperature does not drop to 40 degrees or below. Bring the plants to a warmer environment when temperatures become too cold.

steps.headline: Once the tomato plants have adapted to the cold environment they are ready to plant outdoors.
Plant the heirloom tomatoes well away from non-heirloom plants to prevent cross pollination.
Plant the seedlings in well fertilized soil using the trench method or by digging deep holes.
steps.description: Either way plant the tomatoes so they are planted to their first true leaves.

steps.headline: Apply a starter fertilizer to the transplants.
Stake or use a tomato cage to train the plants.
Water tomato plants often, based on how the plants look, try not to spray the leaves.
steps.description: Water by giving the plants a good soaking.

steps.headline: Take appropriate action to keep pests such as nematodes or the tomato worm at bay.
Save the heirloom tomato seeds for next year's garden or to share with other heirloom tomato farmers.
steps.description: There are seed exchanges available and can be found by doing a net search.

text: Buy your seeds from a reputable source. There are several online sources for heirloom seeds. It's important to start germination early. For most temperate zones, you'll want to start around March. Plant the seeds indoors in small pots about 6 to 8 weeks before moving them to the garden. Some gardeners use foam cups to plant the seeds indoors. Plant the seeds in sterile soil about 1/8-inch deep in the small pots.  Keep the soil moist until the seedlings emerge.  Make sure the seedlings get plenty of light. Use natural sunlight or fluorescent lights. Move the plants to larger pots once leaves appear.  Harden off the seedlings by gradually placing them in a cold environment. Be sure the temperature does not drop to 40 degrees or below. Bring the plants to a warmer environment when temperatures become too cold. Once the tomato plants have adapted to the cold environment they are ready to plant outdoors.  Plant the heirloom tomatoes well away from non-heirloom plants to prevent cross pollination.  Plant the seedlings in well fertilized soil using the trench method or by digging deep holes. Either way plant the tomatoes so they are planted to their first true leaves. Apply a starter fertilizer to the transplants.  Stake or use a tomato cage to train the plants.  Weed plants regularly.  Water tomato plants often, based on how the plants look, try not to spray the leaves. Water by giving the plants a good soaking. Take appropriate action to keep pests such as nematodes or the tomato worm at bay.  Save the heirloom tomato seeds for next year's garden or to share with other heirloom tomato farmers. There are seed exchanges available and can be found by doing a net search.
